fields.description: This book is a classic in the web field. I gave this copy to a client when I got the revised edition. If you have to read one book on the topic of web design / development read this one.
fields.title: Don't Make Me Think

fields.description: The examples are probably a little bit outdated now, but the reasoning remains intact. I've used this book more for ammunition when protecting a sites design from a bad design decision. On that ground it's worth it's weight in gold.
fields.title: Homepage Usability: 50 Websites Deconstructed

fields.description: Thick plot with a strange twist. Perhaps not, but I still use this book for reference. Even though it's quite old the technologies hadn't changed that much until the advent of html5.
fields.title: HTML & XHTML ( Definitive Guide )

fields.description: I read this everyday for about a year and then referred to it everyday for the next three. It's became embedded in my head.
fields.title: CSS: The Definitive Guide

fields.description: At uni we were taught Director. It was 'the' tool back then as CD-ROMs were something that people still wanted. I never did really 'get' lingo and this book got demoted into obscurity in 2nd year when Flash MX came out with video support.
fields.title: Lingo in a Nutshell

fields.description: It helped my foundations in director, but dry rot had already set in from the top as flash became more and more powerful.
fields.title: Director 8 Demystified

fields.description: This was my bible. Initially I toyed with Director as this is what we were taught at UNI, but around the same time flash 5 was beginning to mature.  I found Actionscript much more palatable then Lingo
fields.title: Actionscript - The definitive guide

fields.description: A lecturer at the time (Joel Mills) pointed out to me how verbose perl was compared to this 'php' thing. So that afternoon I went and bought this book. This book was my introduction to php, I used it almost everyday right up until 2005 when I could practically recite it.  The writing style in this book is great and clear. If you have to go back in time to learn php, use this book.
fields.title: Teach yourself php in 24 hours

fields.description: My first 'web development' tech book. I needed a site that I'd designed to 'do' something. Back in the day before php had surged in usage I used perl, though probably very badly.
fields.title: Perl Cookbook

fields.description: Its no secret that Jazz is my favourite style of drumming, so it made sense to get a book by one of the Jazz drumming legends. When I got it i didn't fully pay attention to it, which lead to many bad habits. Some of which I'm still working out now.
fields.title: Gene Krupa Drum Method

fields.description: I never got to the end of this book before it went MIA following the rehersal room move, but it taught me several independence exercises that I still do this day.
fields.title: Complete Modern Drum Set
